posts.post_content:
Paladin, the point of his second ability is for late game. You don't need that many Mountains in late game anyway, and if you draw a Mountain it's no longer a dead draw, but rather a 1/1 goblin.  
Granted, goblin decks shouldn't be running into late game very often, but if you run out of steam before you win, this guy can give you a little jump start.
posts.html:

Posted By: Mike-C (6/30/2012 5:21:26 AM)
Rating:

posts.post_content:
This guy is insane in mid-range aggro goblin decks. Drop a [Goblin Chieftan](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Goblin Chieftan) on your 3rd turn, and then this on your 4th: If you sacrifice all of your lands, you'll end up with four 2/2's and a 4/3, all with haste, for the bargain price of four mana. That's 12 damage in a four-mana package, assuming Ib and his tokens gets through, and it gets even more ridiculous if you dropped a [Goblin Wardriver](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Goblin Wardriver) on your 2nd turn.  
Albeit being very powerful, this card is still fair in the sense that you're putting yourself in a very vulnerable position when sacrificing your lands. You're gaining a temporary advantage, but if your gamble doesn't pay off then and there, you'll be left with no lands and a bunch of small tokens. Even worse is if your opponent manages to land a removal spell on your Chieftan in response to the combat step. Still, I really love this card. It creates exciting moments in the mid-stages in the game, and it's an awesome topdeck once the ga... [(see all)](javascript:void(0);)
posts.html:
This guy is insane in mid-range aggro goblin decks. Drop a Goblin Chieftan on your 3rd turn, and then this on your 4th: If you sacrifice all of your lands, you'll end up with four 2/2's and a 4/3, all with haste, for the bargain price of four mana. That's 12 damage in a four-mana package, assuming Ib and his tokens gets through, and it gets even more ridiculous if you dropped a Goblin Wardriver on your 2nd turn.
Albeit being very powerful, this card is still fair in the sense that you're putting yourself in a very vulnerable position when sacrificing your lands. You're gaining a temporary advantage, but if your gamble doesn't pay off then and there, you'll be left with no lands and a bunch of small tokens. Even worse is if your opponent manages to land a removal spell on your Chieftan in response to the combat step. Still, I really love this card.
